text: Psalm 137
Lament During the Babylonian Exile
By the rivers of Babylon,
there we sat, yes, we wept,
when we remembered Zion.
On \add the\add* willows\f + \fr 137:2 \ft Species of tree uncertain \f* in her midst,
we hung up our lyres.
For there our captors asked of us
words of a song,

and our tormentors\f + \fr 137:3 \ft Only occurring once in the MT, this interpretation is uncertain. The LXX’s “carried us captive” is a guess. If related to the Hebrew root \fqa yll \ft it might have the idea of “mockers/yammerers” \f* \add asked of us\add* jubilation,
“Sing for us from a song of Zion.”
How could we sing the song of Yahweh
in ⸤a foreign land⸥?\f + \fr 137:4 \ft Literally “a land of a foreigner” \f*
If I forget you, O Jerusalem,
let my right hand forget.\f + \fr 137:5 \ft That is, how to play a musical instrument \f*
Let my tongue cling to the roof of my mouth,
if I do not remember you,
if do not I exalt Jerusalem
above my highest joy.
Remember, O Yahweh, against the sons of Edom
the day of Jerusalem,
the ones who said, “Lay \add it\add* bare! Lay \add it\add* bare
to its foundation!”
O daughter of Babylon, about to be devastated,
happy \add shall be he\add* who pays back to you
⸤what you paid out to us⸥.\f + \fr 137:8 \ft Literally “\fq with \ft what you treated us” \f*
Happy \add shall be he\add* who seizes
and smashes your children
against the rock.
